title: RIOT's balance as of late seems.. very poorly tested.
body:
Personally, I am of the belief that winrates do a good job in showing a champion's strength. Now, let's examine how winrates have changed after champions have been touched in recent patches.

Cass- buffed to being one of the highest win rates in the game, both top lane and mid. (I forget the exact number.) But now is nerfed to a proper state. 
Ahri- Buffed to the highest win rate in the game, at 58.5%. Subsequently nerfed to a proper state.

These two are.. sort of okay, I guess? They were broken for a patch but got fixed.

Syndra- Nerfed to what was the lowest win rate in the game. She is still below 43% win rate.
Akali- Nerfed to one of the lowest win rates in the game. She is still below 43% win rate.
Azir- Nerfed to the lowest win rate in the game. He is below a 38% win rate.

Tristana- Nerfed to have the lowest win rate out of any ADC. (below 46%). 

Fizz- Nerfed so that AP Fizz has below a 45% win rate. His AD/bruiser build is balanced now, but was that really RIOT's goal?

I'm just wondering.. how do so many champions end up in either the top 3 or bottom 5 champions for win rate, within 4 patches? This seems to indicate that you aren't capable of accurately predicting the strength of a champion/how much changes will impact them.

replies.body:
> Personally, I am of the belief that winrates do a good job in showing a champion's strength. 

Win rates mostly show whether a champion is easy to play.  It shouldn't surprise when we see Heimerdinger in the top win rates, or Lee Sin in the lowest win rates.  Remember that the top level win rate number includes a ton of really bad players, so ease of use is a paramount virtue.

Win rates become interesting when you see champions that are low skill and low winrate (e.g. Zilean) or high skill and high winrate (e.g. Janna).  These are good candidates for balance changes.

> Cass- buffed to being one of the highest win rates in the game, both top lane and mid. (I forget the exact number.) But now is nerfed to a proper state.
> Ahri- Buffed to the highest win rate in the game, at 58.5%. Subsequently nerfed to a proper state.
> Tristana- Nerfed to have the lowest win rate out of any ADC. (below 46%). 

It's really, really hard to get rework tuning right.  So many things change at once, you lose touch with the balance point.  These results are acceptable.

> Syndra- Nerfed to what was the lowest win rate in the game. She is still below 43% win rate.
> Azir- Nerfed to the lowest win rate in the game. He is below a 38% win rate.

These are pretty annoying.  Both these champs were overnerfed, and it should have been knowable by the balance team.  Someone fell asleep at the switch.

> Akali- Nerfed to one of the lowest win rates in the game. She is still below 43% win rate.

Akali is probably just in purgatory -- being intentionally nerfed out of viability because her play patterns are too reliable.

> Fizz- Nerfed so that AP Fizz has below a 45% win rate. His AD/bruiser build is balanced now, but was that really RIOT's goal?

He's probably fine.  High skill champions shouldn't be expected to have a 50% win rate in average games.

> [{quoted}](name=SmokingPuffin,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=tmm101QE,comment-id=0001,timestamp=2015-02-20T21:15:00.540+0000)

> It's really, really hard to get rework tuning right.  So many things change at once, you lose touch with the balance point.  These results are acceptable.

Out of the champions I listed, I think that Ahri is the most Okay champion to have out of balance. I don't think anyone really predicted her to be that strong.

Cass though, was only overpowered after they buffed her several times. She wasn't reworked into being that strong, she was buffed into being that strong.

As to the high skill cap thing.. I disagree with your assessment, but I suppose that's an opinionated argument.

> Cass though, was only overpowered after they buffed her several times. She wasn't reworked into being that strong, she was buffed into being that strong.

To some extent.  The way I see it, Riot released a Cass rework that was hopelessly undertuned.  Then they did a mini-rework on that rework, with a new passive design and a new poison enhancement mechanic on E.  That one turned out to be hilariously overtuned.  Since then, they made a further nerf and now she's reasonable.

I think this clearly could have been handled better by the balance guys, but it's a B- sort of performance.

> As to the high skill cap thing.. I disagree with your assessment, but I suppose that's an opinionated argument.

It's controversial.  Let me outline my view on it.

1. Some champions scale better with skill than other champions.  This seems fairly clear -- a really good Garen isn't as much better than an average Garen as a really good Lee Sin is from an average Lee Sin.
2. I want the game to be balanced for competitive play.  To me, if a champion is balanced when everyone plays correctly, but too strong when people make tons of mistakes, the solution to that is the player making mistakes improving.
3. If a champion scales well with skill, and should be balanced in competitive play, we should expect them to be weaker at lower elos than champions who do not scale as well with skill.

In practice, you can see many examples of this pattern in the current game balance.  Some low win rate champions are just undertuned; often intentionally so because Riot regrets the kit design.  However, there is also a class of low win rate champions that are actually quite strong, just not in the hands of an average solo queue player.  Examples include:

> {{champion:64}} {{champion:238}} {{champion:38}} {{champion:7}} {{champion:412}}

First of all, I believe that statistics seem to disprove the idea that high skill-cap champions perform significantly better when played by skilled players. 

Zed, http://www.lolking.net/champions/zed&region=all&map=sr&queue=1x1&league=diamond#statistics
Zed appears to not have any improvement in win rate from bronze to diamond.

Vel'Koz http://www.lolking.net/champions/velkoz&region=all&map=sr&queue=1x1&league=bronze#statistics
Appears to have a better win rate in lower Elo, despite having an incredible high skill cap.

Yasuo http://www.lolking.net/champions/yasuo&region=all&map=sr&queue=1x1&league=diamond#statistics
Similarly, Yasuo appears to have a higher win rate at lower Elos. 

What is more important is how well the champion fits into the playstyle at different Elos. Low elo players aren't so much unskilled as they are bad at strategy. 
As such, the mechanics of a champion don't determine or justify their win rate as well as one would think. What is more important is the decisions that the player has to make. (Janna has a MUCH higher win rate in diamond than in bronze. She isn't mechanically intensive so much as she is strategically intensive though.) 

Professional play brings this to an altogether different level though. Through communication, they are able to perform strategies that are not viable in solo queue. Similarly, strategies that capitalize on the enemy's lack of communication are not as viable.
I believe that THIS is the reason that champions like Zed and LeBlanc have much more popularity in competitive play than their win rates in Diamond Solo Queue would suggest. Their ability to "undo" a mistake is invaluable, as it makes them difficult to catch out, even by a coordinated team. Similarly, their mobility allows for them to always follow up the plays that their team is making.

> [{quoted}](name=PentaJump,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=tmm101QE,comment-id=0001000000000000,timestamp=2015-02-21T02:05:52.033+0000)
>
> First of all, I believe that statistics seem to disprove the idea that high skill-cap champions perform significantly better when played by skilled players. 

I need to clarify here.  I'm not talking about high skill cap champions.  I think skill cap isn't being reached, even by really strong players, and therefore isn't so interesting to discuss.  When I say a champion is "high skill", I mean that the marginal returns on increasing skill are higher than the average champion.

For example, Vel'koz has a high skill cap, but he doesn't actually scale with increasing skill all that fast.  You can totally do well with him without doing anything special.  Meanwhile, Fizz absolutely falls on his face unless you are using his kit outplay the opponent on a regular basis.  This is true even though Vel'koz probably has more skill cap in his kit than Fizz does.

Let me mention that solo queue win rate is not so interesting to me, even high elo.  We don't balance basketball around pickup games.  It's also a noisy metric, because players are terrible at picking champions.  For example, Lee Sin has a famously low win rate across all elos, even in diamond, because many players pick him when they can't handle him.  That doesn't mean Lee is a low skill champion or that he's a weak champion.

> Low elo players aren't so much unskilled as they are bad at strategy. 

This is an interesting conjecture.  I'm not totally convinced it's true, but it might be.  I didn't really intend to separate aspects of skill in this discussion.

> As such, the mechanics of a champion don't determine or justify their win rate as well as one would think. What is more important is the decisions that the player has to make. (Janna has a MUCH higher win rate in diamond than in bronze. She isn't mechanically intensive so much as she is strategically intensive though.) 

I certainly agree that there is much more to skill than kit mechanics.  Also, Janna is a good example of a high skill champion that nonetheless doesn't have a particularly high skill cap.

> I believe that THIS is the reason that champions like Zed and LeBlanc have much more popularity in competitive play than their win rates in Diamond Solo Queue would suggest. Their ability to "undo" a mistake is invaluable, as it makes them difficult to catch out, even by a coordinated team. Similarly, their mobility allows for them to always follow up the plays that their team is making.

I'm not sold.  I think the possibility of undoing a mistake is probably more valuable in an environment where more mistakes are made.  I agree that mobility enables more reliable follow ups, but I also think that players like Faker and Bjergsen draw LeBlanc and Zed bans primarily because of their solo kill potential.

I think that Zed and LeBlanc simply have kits that scale better with player skill than most other mids.  Very few solo queue players, even in diamond, have the ability to get appropriate value out of these kits; but when you hit one in solo queue, you feel it very strongly.

I agree that mobility enables more reliable follow ups, but I also think that players like Faker and Bjergsen draw LeBlanc and Zed bans primarily because of their solo kill potential.

So, the reason that I say that being able to undo a mistake is more important in a professional environment, is that...
Often times, a team will engage while some variables are hidden. For example, a couple enemies may be MIA. The engage is done off of the hope that they aren't able to join the fight within a very short period of time. Now, if they do join the fight, then the fight will be lost.
In solo queue, everyone is on a different page. Maybe the ideal strategy at this point is for everyone to retreat. But how do you know that your allies will retreat just because you try to? If your allies don't run away with you, it might be better for you to just fight until you run out of HP. 
In the pro scene, everyone is on the same page. "Retreat" can be a team decision that is made in the middle of a fight. Because of this, champions that are actually capable of retreating are valued more.

Haha, I nearly made it to challenger by playing AP Trist mid/top, with building spellthief's edge first. I'm really open to breaking the meta. 
Fizz isn't in a bad state now, as a whole. AP Fizz is, however, in a bad state. And I really doubt it was RIOT's intention to make bruiser Fizz be the only viable build for him. 
Many of the other changes simply nerfed the champion. There's no real way to break the meta if the changes were flat-out nerfs to the champion.

Using winrate the week after something is released/changed is a bad thing. Yasuo was cried underpowered after release and buffed into a monster until he was re-nerfed. 

But after a month of a  54% winrate something needs to change.

Win rate is actually a bit of a tricky thing. There are FOUR possible states.

Weak - Low win rate - This champion is just outright undertuned.

Hard to play - Low win rate - The people who know what to do, do well. Those who don't, don't do well. Can't be buffed without the first party breaking the champion.

Balanced - Good win rate - Perfect. Don't touch them.

OP - High win rate - Picking this champion makes you flat out more likely to win. Needs a nerf.

Yup recent balance changes have been total trash.

Overnerfing for no reason and then backpedaling on the changes.

Lol its not tested at all.

A side note, AP fizz has less then a 45% win rate, his winrate is just inflated by AD Fizz. AD fizz does everything AP Fizz does at the moment but better and doesn't heavily rely on his ult to get kills so there is really no point in going AP on fizz.
The entire reason AD fizz is being played is due to the amp on his ult...

My personal thinking (or hopes) are that Riot is just taking this time to make some really aggressive changes to the game to shake things up a bit, and then make measured changes/corrections later. All I remember Riot adding to S4 were trinkets; they seem to be adding a lot more new stuff in this early part of this season; thus everything is going to be sort of messy for a while. I'm hoping that this might result in larger systematic changes (rather than small balance tweaks) in the future, and also correction of problems that have been building up over the years, and then they'll return to measured changes and tweaks after the dust has settled. That's at least what I'm thinking (or hoping) for.
